+1 Really interesting feature

You can use an expression (calculated) column or metric to `/ 100` first. Otherwise to know what's possible you'll have to refer to this:
https://github.com/d3/d3-format
Which seems to be based off of:
https://docs.python.org/3/library/string.html#formatspec
If you have hundreds of AMs maybe you have an IT that can support providing separated views for the same data and find a way to build slices / dashboard programmatically?

Thanks for the replies. @mistercrunch I'm using Chrome 61.

First I though that my loadbalancer was eating the error message but it appears not to since I can see the error in the network console.

I'll try to see how I can fix that, will open a PR if I find anything

Right; that could work, but maintaining a single dashboard has 2 key benefits I can think of:

1. Less clutter. 100 AMs = 100 views = at least 100 slices = at least 100 dashboards (in this scenario where data separation is important).

2. Any updates or enhancements made to a master view or master dashboard would propagate to all AMs.
I'm wondering how hard could it be to add "virtual" slice / dashboard that you can connect to different datasources.

@georgeke
@xrmx

It probably wouldn't be that bad, but the code for the dashboard filters is pretty all over the place. Considering https://github.com/apache/incubator-superset/issues/3617, I think the best solution, looking forward, is to rethink the dashboard filters a bit and rewrite a good amount of the code.

I mean, the time options are 'hidden' inside `extra_filters` with `__` prepended and then pulled out later.
What if exploring a slice from the dashboard that has filters would display these filters in a separate `Dashboard Filters` section that do not save with the slice?
This has been fixed in #3329. Just upgrade to the most recent superset version (currently 0.20.3).

@Mogball This may be a useful approach. Maybe the user could then drag and drop (or transfer otherwise) filters to the section where the permanent filters reside.

Another feasible way might be to only ask on saving the slice, whether the filters carried over from the dashboard should be permanently included into the slice. This approach would postpone this decision  until it is eventually required.

@xrmx I'm afraid I am not the right person for this job, as I'm not at all a skilled programmer. I have zero knowledge in JavaScript and never even tried to build superset by myself. I wouldn't even know where to start tackling this issue.

If I had the skills, I'd rather start with #3007, as this one bothers me even more. However, the overhead of trying to get myself into this business is currently not bearable for me :-(

related: https://github.com/apache/incubator-superset/issues/3609

I have some thoughts on this. First the dashboard view should be upfront about which dashboard filters are applied / not applied to each widget as there can be complex logic and conditions at play (`filter_immune_slices` configuration on the dash, and whether the underlying datasource has the field set as "filterable" for instance)

I'm thinking a `text-primary` colored filter icon on the widget header (should be always visible, not only on-hover like other widget-header icons). By hovering the filter icon we'd show clearly which dashboard-level filters are applied and which ones are disregarded.

Now about the explore view. When the explore view derives from the original slice, we should be very clear about this. So say the saved slice has a certain metric, and I change that metric to another one, then we need to surface that this is an altered version of this slice, and ideally provide context as to the exact diff between the original slice and the current view. This could be done with an `altered` style="danger" label right of slice title, and with a tooltip on that label with the diff list of each control label along with its value-before, value-after.

In the case where we'd navigate from a filtered dashboard, you'd land on the explore view with that `altered` label showing loud and clear.

@graceguo-supercat  is "reactifactoring" the dashboard view here https://github.com/apache/incubator-superset/pull/3581 and wouldn't start the dashboard view changes until that's landed. The work for the `altered` tag on the explore view could probably start anytime though.
agreed with @Mogball , the rewrite of the dashboard app taking place now would require rewriting most tests as well anyways.

The proper way to do this so that it applies throughout the app (CRUD, REST, ...) is this way:
https://github.com/apache/incubator-superset/blob/master/superset/views/core.py#L126

I think something similar needs to be done on top of BaseDatasource:
https://github.com/apache/incubator-superset/blob/master/superset/connectors/base/views.py#L6
One related thing that I've been thinking about is adding more grain to the grid dashboard snapping grid.

@rhunwicks thanks for the analysis! Can we add the session cleanup in a overriden `add_permissions_menu` in security/sqla/manager.py? Like the following untested:

```
diff --git a/flask_appbuilder/security/sqla/manager.py b/flask_appbuilder/security/sqla/manager.py
index c75ba548..138914e1 100644
--- a/flask_appbuilder/security/sqla/manager.py
+++ b/flask_appbuilder/security/sqla/manager.py
@@ -251,6 +251,10 @@ class SecurityManager(BaseSecurityManager):
                 log.error(c.LOGMSG_ERR_SEC_DEL_PERMISSION.format(str(e)))
                 self.get_session.rollback()
 
+    def add_permissions_menu(self, view_menu_name):
+        super(SecurityManager, self).add_permissions_menu(self, view_menu_name)
+        self.get_session.close()
+
     # ----------------------------------------------
     #       PRIMITIVES VIEW MENU
     #----------------------------------------------
```

Like removing the credential page, bookmarking dashboard page so directly can be rendered, and removing user role option.
Last but not the least  Adding custom visualization.

I want to integrate superset in one of my product. Which actually running on Angular2 and Node.js.
